sections.title: The Four Verb Stems of Classical Tibetan
sections.content: Classical Tibetan verbs can have up to four distinct stems: present, past, future, and imperative. Unlike English where tense is marked with auxiliary words and endings (-ed, -ing, will), Tibetan changes the verb root itself through prefixes and suffixes. These four stems are fundamental to reading Buddhist texts: narrative sutras use past stems to describe the Buddha's deeds, prayers use future stems for aspirations, and meditation manuals use imperatives for instructions. Additionally, two auxiliary verbs — ཡིན (to be) and ཡོད (to exist/have) — play a central role in forming complete sentences. In this lesson, we will study examples drawn from the Heart Sutra, the 37 Practices of Bodhisattvas, and the Aspiration Prayer of Samantabhadra.

words.english: to do, to make (pres. / past / fut. / imp.)

example.transliteration: nyan bsam sgom byed pa rgyal sras lag len yin
example.english: Listening, reflecting, and meditating is the practice of bodhisattvas.
example.note: From the 37 Practices of Bodhisattvas, verse 1. བྱེད is the present stem.

words.english: to teach, to show (pres. / past / fut. / imp.)

example.transliteration: shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pas stong nyid ston
example.english: The Perfection of Wisdom shows emptiness.
example.note: In the spirit of the Heart Sutra. སྟོན is the present stem — showing as a general truth.

words.english: to meditate, to cultivate (pres. / past / fut. / imp.)

example.transliteration: rgyal sras kyis bdag med bsgoms
example.note: From the 37 Practices. བསྒོམས is the past stem — the meditation was completed.

words.english: to go (pres. / past / fut. / imp.) — irregular

example.english: Sentient beings wander in the ocean of samsara.
example.note: From the 37 Practices, verse 1. འགྲོ is the present stem of this irregular verb.

example.transliteration: kun tu bzang pos mchod pa bla na med pa byin
example.note: From Samantabhadra's Aspiration Prayer. བྱིན is the past stem of སྦྱིན.

words.english: to protect, to guard (pres. / past / fut. / imp.)

example.transliteration: rgyal sras kyis tshul khrims bsrungs
example.note: From the 37 Practices. བསྲུངས is the past stem — discipline was kept.

words.english: to be born, to arise (pres. / past / fut. / imp.)

example.transliteration: gzhan la snying rje chen po skyes
example.note: From the 37 Practices. སྐྱེས is the past stem — compassion has arisen.

words.english: to read, to recite (pres. / past / fut. / imp.)

example.transliteration: dge slong gis shes rab snying po bklags
example.english: The monk recited the Heart Sutra.
example.note: བཀླགས is the past stem of བཀླག — the recitation was completed.

example.transliteration: 'di ni rgyal sras kyi lag len yin
example.english: This is the practice of bodhisattvas.
example.note: The refrain of the 37 Practices. ཡིན identifies what something is.

example.transliteration: sems can kun la bde ba'i rgyu yod
example.english: In all sentient beings, there are causes of happiness.
example.literalTranslation: Sentient-beings all to happiness's causes exist
example.note: From the Four Immeasurables. ཡོད expresses existence.

sections.title: Present Stem (ད་ལྟ་བ)
sections.explanation: The present stem describes actions that are currently happening, habitual, or generally true. In Buddhist texts, it appears in descriptions of general truths and ongoing practices. The present stem is often the base form of the verb. It can be combined with the auxiliary ཡོད to emphasize continuity ('is doing'), or used alone for general statements.

examples.transliteration: rgyal sras kyis sems can kun gyi don byed
examples.english: The bodhisattva works for the benefit of all sentient beings.
examples.note: From the 37 Practices. བྱེད is the present stem of 'to do' — expressing the bodhisattva's ongoing activity.

examples.transliteration: spyan ras gzigs kyis 'gro ba la thugs rjes gzigs
examples.english: Avalokiteshvara looks upon beings with compassion.
examples.note: In the spirit of the Heart Sutra's opening. གཟིགས is the honorific present stem of བལྟ (to look).

examples.english: Sentient beings wander in the ocean of samsara.
examples.note: From the 37 Practices, verse 1. འགྲོ is irregular: past ཕྱིན, imperative སོང.

sections.title: Past Stem (འདས་པ)
sections.explanation: The past stem describes actions that have been completed. It is the most common stem in narrative sutras, which recount the Buddha's life and teachings. Past stems are typically formed by adding the prefix བ- and/or the suffix -ས to the root. For example: སྟོན → བསྟན (taught), སྒོམ → བསྒོམས (meditated), སྲུང → བསྲུངས (protected). Some verbs have irregular past stems, like འགྲོ → ཕྱིན (went).

examples.transliteration: spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug gis phung po lnga stong par bltas
examples.english: Noble Avalokiteshvara saw the five aggregates as empty.
examples.note: From the Heart Sutra. བལྟས is the past stem of བལྟ (to look). The བ- prefix and -ས suffix both mark the past.

examples.transliteration: kun tu bzang pos smon lam btab
examples.note: From Samantabhadra's Aspiration Prayer. བཏབ is the past stem of འདེབས (to make/plant) — here meaning 'set forth' prayers.

examples.transliteration: rgyal sras kyis bdag nyid gzhan dang brjes
examples.english: The bodhisattva exchanged self for others.
examples.note: From the 37 Practices, verse 11. བརྗེས is the past stem of བརྗེ (to exchange). This is the core Mahayana practice of tonglen.

sections.title: Future Stem (མ་འོངས་པ)
sections.rule: Expressing intentions, aspirations, and actions to come
sections.explanation: The future stem describes actions that have not yet happened. It is very common in prayers, vows, and aspirational texts — expressing what one intends or wishes to do. In many verbs, the future stem resembles the present but with a བ- prefix: སྒོམ → བསྒོམ (will meditate), སྲུང → བསྲུང (will protect). Some verbs share the same form for present and future (འགྲོ), or past and future (བསྟན). The future is often used with particles like པར་བྱ (shall do) or བར་འགྱུར (will become).

examples.transliteration: bdag gis 'gro ba kun gyi don bsgrub
examples.english: I shall accomplish the benefit of all beings.
examples.note: From Samantabhadra's Aspiration Prayer. བསྒྲུབ is the future stem of སྒྲུབ (to accomplish).

examples.transliteration: dge ba thams cad byang chub tu bsngo
examples.english: I shall dedicate all virtue toward enlightenment.
examples.note: From Samantabhadra's Aspiration Prayer. བསྔོ is the future stem of སྔོ (to dedicate). Dedication of merit is the closing act of all Buddhist practice.

examples.transliteration: chos kyi 'khor lo bskor bar bya
examples.english: The wheel of dharma shall be turned.
examples.note: From Samantabhadra's Aspiration Prayer. བསྐོར་བར་བྱ is a compound future: 'shall be turned'. Requesting the turning of the dharma wheel is one of the seven limbs of practice.

sections.title: Imperative Stem (སྐུལ་ཚིག)
sections.explanation: The imperative stem is used for direct commands, instructions, and exhortations. It is common in meditation manuals where the teacher gives instructions, and in ritual texts. The imperative typically drops the བ- prefix found in past/future stems and may add a -ས suffix: བསྒོམ → སྒོམས (meditate!), བསྲུང → སྲུངས (protect!). Some irregular verbs have unique imperative forms: འགྲོ → སོང (go!), བྱེད → བྱོས (do it!).

examples.note: A classic meditation instruction. ལྟོས is the imperative of བལྟ (to look). The བ- prefix is dropped.
From the spirit of the 37 Practices. སྤོངས is the imperative of སྤོང (to abandon). The -ས suffix marks the imperative.

examples.transliteration: sems can gyi don du byos
examples.english: Act for the benefit of sentient beings!
examples.note: བྱོས is the irregular imperative of བྱེད (to do). This exhortation captures the entire Mahayana motivation.

sections.title: Practice Exercises
sections.description: Apply your understanding of verb tenses and stems with exercises based on classical Buddhist texts

keyPoints.text: The present stem describes ongoing or habitual actions and is often the base form of the verb
The present stem can combine with ཡོད to emphasize continuity
The past stem describes completed actions and typically adds a བ- prefix and/or -ས suffix
Past stems are the most common in narrative sutras recounting the Buddha's deeds
The future stem expresses intentions and aspirations, often used with པར་བྱ (shall be done)
Future stems are common in prayers, vows, and aspirational texts
The imperative stem gives commands and instructions, dropping the བ- prefix and often adding -ས
Imperatives are common in meditation manuals and guru's directives
